urn:contentItem:6FBC-W403-RWBG-J3SX-00000-00Considering Equity in Green Infrastructure Using an Integrative Planning Framework for Green Infrastructure Implementation2025-09-15T21:07:37Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisPg. 179-201Considering Equity in Green Infrastructure Using an Integrative Planning Framework for Green Infrastructure Implementation

Declaration of Conflicting InterestsThe author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

FundingThe author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This material is based upon work supported by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security under Grant Award Number 2015-ST-061-ND0001-01.

Juita-Elena (Wie) YusufTom AllenMarina SaitgalinaJennifer L. WhytlawJoshua BehrKhairul A. AnuarNicole HuttonOgechukwu Nwandu-VincentABSTRACT

In coastal communities, green infrastructure can be part of the infrastructure investment strategy to revitalize existing infrastructure and provide protection from flooding, erosion, and other coastal hazards. This article asks the question: What are key equity considerations related to green infrastructure planning for coastal resilience? We answer this question using the voices of research experts, practitioners, and community members who participated in a virtual workshop designed to identify key questions and concerns about coastal resilience and social equity. These research and practice perspectives are synthesized using an integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation that was developed to answer the research question. Our findings identify equity touchpoints as they relate to four cross-cutting themes: (1) stakeholder engagement and public participation, (2) trade-offs and multiple benefits, (3) resources and capacity, and (4) data, metrics, and analysis.

FULL TEXTIntroduction

Much of the critical infrastructure in the U.S. is either aging or requires significant repair. Simultaneously, coastal flooding due to extreme weather events and sea level rise is of growing global concern (Barbier, 2014; Sutton-Grier et al., 2015). Outdated and deteriorating infrastructure places coastal communities at risk from increasingly frequent and intense coastal storm events and rising sea levels. Therefore, investments in coastal infrastructure are urgently needed; however, these investments should complement the ecosystems and natural resources that underlie the economic and social well-being of communities. Over the past 50 years, efforts have been made to integrate built infrastructure with natural landscape features, often termed “green” infrastructure, in order to sustain and restore valuable ecosystem functions and services. For example, significant advances have been made in implementing green infrastructure approaches for stormwater management, wastewater treatment, and drinking water conservation and delivery. Similarly, green infrastructure can be implemented for flood prevention and coastal erosion protection purposes, contributing to coastal resilience of communities along the U.S. coastlines.

In the face of climate change, it is critical to the health and prosperity of communities and the economy to think differently about infrastructure along the coast, especially that which helps protect U.S. coasts from extreme events. To date, built infrastructure, including sea walls, levees, culverts, bulkheads, and other hardened structures, have dominated approaches to coastal protection (Spalding et al., 2014). However, an increasing body of research shows that green infrastructure, as a subset of natural- or nature-based solutions (NNBS), such as wetlands, urban forests, rain gardens, and open space, reduces the risk of coastal flooding and erosion and provides other social and economic benefits. Green infrastructure may be more cost-effective in the long run in comparison to built or gray infrastructure, and green infrastructure can strengthen the social, economic, and ecological resilience of coasts while supporting the provisioning of coastal ecosystem services and preventing the loss of life and property (Sutton-Grier et al., 2015). As Sutton-Grier et al. (2015, p. 139) note, the time is ripe for incorporating green infrastructure and other NNBS into coastal planning as a way to enhance coastal resilience.

Planning for coastal resilience, however, is rife with biases concerning equity and power (Yusuf et al., 2022). Planning efforts must ensure that all voices are heard, address disparate impacts, and increase resilience equitably. Equity challenges arise when goals and power are in conflict, when institutions both help and hinder resilience efforts, and when community participation processes are designed without consideration of differences across diverse groups in the community. Given the cost, durability, lifespan, and impacts of infrastructure, planning practices that do not explicitly consider equity can exacerbate injustices associated with infrastructure and land use approaches that favor privileged groups while excluding marginalized communities. Given the concern for equity in the infrastructure planning process and the growing attention to incorporating green infrastructure to enhance coastal resilience, this article asks the question: What are key equity considerations related to green infrastructure planning for coastal resilience? We answer this question using the voices of research experts and practitioners who participated in a virtual workshop designed to identify questions and concerns for coastal resilience and social equity. We developed an integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation as a way to bring together the issues raised by researchers and practitioners pertaining to equity in implementing green infrastructure for coastal resilience.

Background and LiteratureGreen Infrastructure

A changing climate coupled with increasing severity and frequency of hazards has worsened the risks of aging infrastructure and lowered the expected life of current and future built structures in coastal communities. Investing in NNBS and green infrastructure can provide greater protection for coastal communities while making it easier to maintain it over the long term (Sutton-Grier et al., 2018).

Green infrastructure can be defined as a strategically planned and managed network of natural and semi-natural features that, while having the same objectives as grey or built infrastructure (e.g., coastal risk reduction), also serves ecological functions such as absorbing floodwaters and improving water quality, in addition to supporting societal functions such as physical activity and recreation (Barbier, 2014; Palmer et al., 2015; Rouse & Bunster-Ossa, 2018; Sutton-Grier et al., 2018; Woodruff et al., 2021). Green infrastructure has become a part of the infrastructure landscape in the U.S. and beyond as the existing gray infrastructure ages and needs to be repaired or replaced. Recognition that built infrastructure can have negative environmental impacts and may increase vulnerability to coastal hazards such as flooding and storms has increased attention to green infrastructure as an alternative. The integration of green infrastructure into the built environment provides additional benefits of conserving, sustaining, and restoring ecosystem functions and services to local communities (Arkema et al., 2017; Singhvi et al., 2022; Sutton-Grier et al., 2018; Sutton-Grier et al., 2015). Green infrastructure projects implemented to reduce vulnerability often simultaneously achieve additional societal, environmental, and economic objectives.

From a coastal resilience perspective, green infrastructure can reduce wave energy, coastal erosion, and flood hazards (Sutton-Grier et al., 2018). Models by the insurance industry, for example, estimate that wetlands have saved more than $600 million in avoided flooding damages and that during Hurricane Sandy, communities behind marshes experienced 20% less property losses (Narayan et al., 2017). Living shorelines, an example of green infrastructure, offer erosion protection of waterfront properties, while stream-design culverts can restore natural tidal flow and reduce flood damage to roads and adjacent properties (Gillespie et al., 2014).

Green infrastructure has become a key component of urban resilience (Lennon & Scott, 2014; Meerow & Newell, 2017; Rouse & Bunster-Ossa, 2018; Woodruff et al., 2021), as part of an infrastructure investment strategy to revitalize existing infrastructure and protect coastal communities. Coastal communities will benefit most from planning approaches that prioritize the inclusion of green infrastructure in infrastructure upgrades, replacements, and new investments (Arkema et al., 2013; Edwards et al., 2013; Sutton-Grier et al., 2018, p. 6; Sutton-Grier et al., 2015). By investing in green infrastructure, communities can delay, reduce, or potentially eliminate the need for larger, more expensive interventions (Abunnasr et al., 2015). In the words of Sutton-Grier et al. (2018), investment in green infrastructure “equates to good stewardship of taxpayer dollars” (p. 9).

Green infrastructure can help address many of the planning issues that communities struggle with (Rouse & Bunster-Ossa, 2018) by providing a solution that establishes connections across these interrelated systems - transportation, land use, housing, environment, economic development, among others - and identifies mutually beneficial strategies. However, where green infrastructure is incorporated into various plans, stormwater runoff has been narrowly the focus (Meerow & Newell, 2017). Planning approaches that utilize green infrastructure more comprehensively to mitigate various hazards while leveraging other societal, economic, and environmental benefits are less prevalent. Broader integration of green infrastructure into planning and implementation will require public and political acceptance, factoring in the different planning stages and alignment with other policy domains. However, like other nature-based solutions, green infrastructure has yet to be incorporated into policy, planning, and governance (Connop et al., 2016; Kabisch et al., 2016; Wickenberg et al., 2021). Collier et al. (2023) point to challenges arising from issues related to governance, equity, limitations of tacit and experiential knowledge, and cross-sector collaboration. Gaps in knowledge also pose challenges to green infrastructure planning, such as the lack of understanding of different stages of implementation (Dushkova & Haase, 2020; Kabisch et al., 2016) and processes and approaches to support mainstreaming of green infrastructure into current policies and processes (Collier et al., 2023; Connop et al., 2016; Zuniga-Teran et al., 2020).

Green Infrastructure Implementation

Several frameworks exist for green infrastructure implementation. For example, Connop et al. (2016) offer a conceptual framework of green infrastructure in the urban context, focused on the planning cycle. Raymond et al. (2017) provide an assessment framework for planning and governance of green infrastructure in an urban context, focused on the strategic planning and implementation phases. van der Jagt et al. (2019) develop a guiding framework for the co-creation of green infrastructure in the urban context, focused on the implementation phase.

Much of the literature has focused on green infrastructure in an urban context (Meerow & Newell, 2017; Raymond et al., 2017; Woodruff et al., 2021) but green infrastructure can also be implemented in rural communities. There is a need to study green infrastructure in a broader context beyond just urban environments. This study examines social equity issues as they apply across urban and rural landscapes and focuses on implementing green infrastructure. Specifically, implementation is defined as “context-specific actions and processes that deliberately seek to respond to identified societal challenges and are constrained or enabled by several contextual conditions” (Wickenberg et al., 2021, p. 45). These contextual conditions, such as actors, networks, knowledge, learning, institutions, legislation, power relations, governance structures, and resources (van der Jagt et al., 2019), can introduce issues and concerns regarding equity and justice into green infrastructure implementation. There is a need to assess the justice implications of green infrastructure and how green infrastructure connects to just and equitable communities (Haase et al., 2017; Sekulova et al., 2021).

An Integrative Planning Framework for Green Infrastructure Implementation

To better understand and situate justice and equity issues in the green infrastructure planning process, we developed a framework for the implementation of green infrastructure capital projects that is adapted from three different planning frameworks. These three frameworks are: (1) the urban planning framework (Raymond et al., 2017; Wickenberg et al., 2021), (2) the capital management and budgeting process (Srithongrung et al., 2019), and (3) the Connecting Nature framework (Collier et al., 2023). Our integrative planning framework of green infrastructure implementation, summarized in Figure 1, places green infrastructure implementation as embedded within a broader process. According to this framework, green infrastructure implementation is distinct from but intertwined with preceding (strategic planning) and subsequent (maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation) phases. Information, decisions, and actions flow between the phases in this process.Figure 1.Integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation.

The strategic planning phase encompasses many different planning processes that relate to green infrastructure broadly, such as comprehensive planning, land use planning, hazard mitigation planning, capital planning, transportation planning, and resilience planning. However, comprehensive planning, as the primary policy document of local governments that typically addresses land use, transportation, housing, environment, and economic development, is the primary mechanism through which green infrastructure is planned for among cities in the US (Woodruff et al., 2021).

There are recommended practices for integrating green infrastructure into plans (McDonald et al., 2005; Rouse & Bunster-Ossa, 2018), but case study research has found that while green infrastructure principles have been integrated into planning activities, these are not always explicitly addressed as green infrastructure projects for implementation (GRETA - GReen Infrastructure: Enhancing Biodiversity and EcosysTem Services for TerritoriAl Development: Final Synthesis Report, 2019; Kim & Tran, 2018).

The strategic planning phase includes defining goals for green infrastructure (Collier et al., 2023; McDonald et al., 2005), conducting inventory and needs analyses of green infrastructure (Srithongrung et al., 2019), including an assessment of the landscape context and ecosystem service needs of the community (Collier et al., 2023), and identifying technical, management, and governance components required for green infrastructure planning and project implementation (Collier et al., 2023). This phase also encompasses the budgeting and financial management elements of planning (Srithongrung et al., 2019) needed for the capital management of green infrastructure planning and to ensure plans translate into action. Activities during the planning phase include project prioritization, determining financing strategies (McDonald et al., 2005; Srithongrung et al., 2019), and developing a budget for implementing projects (Srithongrung et al., 2019) along with other implementation tools (McDonald et al., 2005). This planning phase sets the stage for the execution and successful delivery of green infrastructure projects, such as through conducting public participation and stakeholder engagement strategies to develop buy-in and support for green infrastructure projects, establishing cross-departmental and multi-sectoral collaborations with assigned roles and responsibilities for project delivery, ranking and prioritizing projects for implementation, and identifying specific funding sources and financing strategies.

The implementation phase is at the heart of the integrative implementation framework for green infrastructure planning. This phase encompasses green infrastructure project delivery, execution, and management. It includes processes that support implementation, such as conducting environmental impact assessment, executing the partnerships and collaborations determined during the planning phase, obtaining funding through specific financing strategies (e.g., grants or municipal bonds), acquisition and contracting for specific project tasks, and managing project execution, for example through reporting and monitoring of budget status and contracted work. This phase includes stakeholder involvement in project delivery and communicating stories and achievements during implementation. In preparation for the planning framework’s subsequent phase, the implementation phase also involves developing and putting in place assessment plans and data collection methods for monitoring and evaluation.

Funding for coastal infrastructure projects is always challenging and consequently requires commitment from multiple levels of governance and sectors. Funding considerations are a key part of the implementation phase, as financing strategies must be implemented to provide funding matched to specific green infrastructure projects for implementation (den Heijer & Coppens, 2023). In the U.S., there has been a significant growth in federal investment for the implementation of green infrastructure projects (Sutton-Grier et al., 2015; Zimmerman et al., 2019). Federal, state, and local governments have begun to rely on various mechanisms to promote the adoption and implementation of NNBS such as green infrastructure (Sutton-Grier et al., 2018; Zimmerman et al., 2019). For example, there has been growing interest in using green bonds, resilience bonds, and environmental impact bonds to finance green infrastructure projects (Uzsoki et al., 2021). Similarly, state infrastructure banks that have been used for transportation projects (Ryu, 2007; Yusuf & Liu, 2008) can potentially be used to encourage and fund green infrastructure options embedded within transportation projects (Colgan, 2017).

The maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation phase of the integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation focuses on ongoing management and maintenance of green infrastructure, monitoring and evaluation of infrastructure quality and performance, and adaptation to ensure long-term sustainability (Collier et al., 2023). The thrust of this phase is continuously monitoring and assessing the impacts of green infrastructure and linking the results to decision making such as feeding into the next iteration of comprehensive planning or providing information about disaster reduction impacts to inform hazard mitigation planning. Important outcomes include identifying lessons learned, determining if and how projects can be scaled or replicated in other settings, and analysis of how projects can be integrated into planning, policy, and regulations. The maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation phase mirrors the stewardship phase of the Connecting Nature Framework (Collier et al., 2023). It also calls for stakeholder participation such as by establishing partnerships and collaboration for project management and operation, increasing awareness of and educating about green infrastructure, and advocating for green infrastructure projects.

Several intertwined concerns cut across the three phases (shown in Figure 1): (1) collaborating for stakeholder engagement and public participation; (2) trade-offs and multiple benefits that factor into benefit-cost analysis and return on investment determination; (3) resources and capacity; and (4) data, metrics, and analysis. All four concerns may also have implications for justice and equity as they apply to the implementation of green infrastructure.

First, Wickenberg et al. (2021) emphasized the importance of collaboration with and among stakeholders, and especially the public. Green infrastructure implementation frameworks such as those by Connop et al. (2016) identify collaboration as a “pre-requisite for practically applicable knowledge needed for implementation” (Wickenberg et al., 2021, p. 48). Similarly, during the strategic planning phase, research and practice have recognized the importance of public participation (McDonald et al., 2005; Rouse & Bunster-Ossa, 2018; Woodruff et al., 2021). “A participatory planning process is critical to provide necessary input to ensure that needs are met and to garner public support” (Woodruff et al., 2021, p. 1581). The focus on collaboration to ensure stakeholder engagement and public participation that is sustained across the three phases also supports three of the four critical needs identified by (Woodruff et al., 2021) for improving green infrastructure planning in coastal communities. These three needs are: (1) articulating a shared definition of green infrastructure planning and the landscape components it includes, (2) educating the public on the benefits of green infrastructure, and (3) building collaboration vertically to regional systems and horizontally to neighboring jurisdictions.

This idea of collaboration that emphasizes the public, however, raises justice and equity concerns, such as those related to participation in the collaborative process, posing questions about authority to collaborate, resource needs, voice, legitimacy, and ownership. This highlights the need to involve and engage populations and stakeholders who may benefit the most from green infrastructure projects despite high costs or low returns on investment and those who may experience negative consequences of green infrastructure, such as increased property values and displacement.

Second, green infrastructure offers ecosystem services and other benefits that need to be considered as plans are made, projects are prioritized and designed, and stakeholders and the public are engaged. Green infrastructure projects may not be prioritized if decisions are made based on short-term construction costs without considering long-term maintenance and repair costs and the co-benefits offered by green infrastructure (Sutton-Grier et al., 2018). Investments in green infrastructure “can pay dividends well into the future by reducing the need for continued investment” (Sutton-Grier et al., 2018, p. 6). However, it is important to recognize that for coastal communities, the benefits of green infrastructure extend beyond coastal protection to include other co-benefits (e.g., improving water quality, providing recreation, and supporting biodiversity) that may be difficult to measure and value (Sutton-Grier et al., 2015). These benefits should be considered across the integrative planning framework of green infrastructure implementation.

While green infrastructure can provide multiple social benefits, there is unequal access to these benefits (Apparicio et al., 2012; Jesdale et al., 2013). Consequently, planning for green infrastructure needs to address the disproportionate benefits and costs across the populations affected by these decisions. Addressing how green infrastructure can link interrelated benefits and issues and build broader coalitions for action is important for successful implementation of green infrastructure in the long term.

The third interconnected theme relates to resources and capacity to support green infrastructure planning. Collier et al. (2023) lists seven elements needed for designing and implementing green infrastructure that are fundamentally about resources and capacity. These include technical know-how for green infrastructure design, governance structures, financing and business models, markets and enterprises for green infrastructure, co-production for stakeholder involvement, reflexive monitoring of the planning process to capture lessons learned and adapt the process, and impact assessment via indicators for monitoring and evaluating implementation. These resources and capacity, such as capacity and expertise for co-production and impact assessment, are connected to the other cross-cutting themes.

Finally, the need for data, metrics, and analysis feeds into strategic planning, informs implementation, and supports maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation. The importance of data, metrics, and analysis begins with the strategic planning phase, where McDonald et al. (2005) emphasized the importance of collecting and compiling information needed to establish priorities and map a future green infrastructure network. Data is also needed to inform the implementation phase by providing metrics to track the progress of different green infrastructure projects. Project execution metrics and other performance tracking data are needed to support project management, oversee contractors executing different green infrastructure projects, and report budget status. Finally, data is also needed to support maintenance activities, and for monitoring and evaluating the extent to which the green infrastructure project is achieving the expected benefits.

Methodology

The research question is answered using both research and practice perspectives sought through participation in a virtual national workshop designed to identify key questions and concerns for equity and coastal resilience. This workshop, titled ‘Making Waves in Equitable Coastal Resilience: A National Workshop on Social Equity and Coastal Resilience,’ was held in November 2022 as three half-day virtual sessions. It was funded by the US Department of Homeland Security through the Coastal Resilience Center at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Across all three days of the workshop, there were 113 total participants from coastal areas across the eastern seaboard and gulf coast and representing a range of sectors, but predominantly from research and academic institutions. Twenty-eight percent of participants represented the federal government, 11% represented state government agencies, and 9% were affiliated with local governments. Eleven percent of workshop participants represented nonprofit or community organizations. The remaining were faculty and researchers.

The workshop was designed to bring together academics, researchers, practitioners, and community members to develop an organizing framework for applied and engaged research in coastal resilience and social equity, addressing topics such as infrastructure planning, coastal squeeze, and emergency and disaster management. The first day of the workshop included topical breakout sessions. Upon registration, workshop participants were asked to prioritize the topics for discussion, which included the broad issue of infrastructure planning, and they were assigned to breakout sessions on the first day that matched their top two priorities. Two breakout sessions were held on the topic of equity in infrastructure planning for coastal resilience, and participants in these sessions indicated that infrastructure planning was a priority topic for discussion regarding equity and coastal resilience. Each breakout discussion group was led by one facilitator and had one note-taker. Both discussion sessions address the same questions (listed in Table 1).Table 1.Discussion Questions.

There were 14 participants in one breakout session and 17 participants in the second breakout session, with 31 total participants in the breakout discussion sessions on infrastructure planning and equitable coastal resilience. The breakout discussion included practitioners and researchers, which was similar to the overall workshop participation. Across the 31 participants, 11 were practitioners (4 representing federal agencies such as NOAA, EPA, and NIST; 5 were with state government agencies from North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia, and 2 represented local governments in Virginia and South Carolina) and 20 were faculty or researchers from universities in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, New York, Oregon, and Texas.

The breakout sessions were recorded, and the discussion transcribed for analysis. Transcripts of the small group discussion were individually reviewed, coded into common themes, and analyzed for overall findings with group consensus of all team members. The analysis focused on themes related to the integrative planning framework of green infrastructure implementation. Findings were manually organized according to broad themes and illustrative quotes from workshop participants were identified.

Findings

Findings from the workshop identified issues relevant to equity and coastal resilience across the three phases of the integrative planning framework of green infrastructure implementation. Overall, workshop participants described a lengthy process in terms of time and resources, and where proposed solutions are considered and studied, stakeholder support gathered, funding and financing identified, and eventually adopted through the budget process or public referendum. Workshop participants identified different equity touchpoints in the planning process, such as awareness of green infrastructure and the ability to pursue projects, as well as who pays and who benefits.

We organize the themes arising out of workshop discussion regarding equity around four crosscutting issues of stakeholder engagement and public participation, trade-offs and multiple benefits, resources and capacity, and data, metrics, and analysis (see Figure 1) and how these issues span the three phases of the integrative framework for green infrastructure implementation – strategic planning, implementation, and maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation.

Stakeholder engagement and public participation: Lack of buy-in due to limited awareness and distrust of government

According to workshop participants, a critical factor for green infrastructure implementation was gaining acceptance of and support for green infrastructure. As succinctly summarized by a workshop participant, ‘You need “buy-in.’” As noted by another participant, “The participatory nature of coming up with these [green infrastructure] solutions has really been important in some of the communities that I’ve engaged with.” However, across all three phases of the integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation there were equity challenges resulting from limited stakeholder engagement and public participation. One participant explained that “the community tends to be very accepting of them… having more knowledge [is] actually really, really helpful.” Workshop participants noted low levels of awareness about green infrastructure options to support coastal resilience. However, there were also few efforts to engage stakeholders and the general public on issues related to green infrastructure, further limiting awareness and knowledge of the opportunities provided by green infrastructure.

Workshop participants noted that green infrastructure “is not the first thing that comes to mind when people think of resilience,” and there is “a lack of awareness on the part of the community, either among the local elected officials or the residents.” The limited awareness of green infrastructure is illustrated in these statements made by workshop participants:• “In terms of a mitigation project that could get funding following a disaster, I think sea wall, breakwater, the traditional hardened structures along the coast, and green infrastructure didn’t jump to mind right off the bat.”• “I think a lot of people, they understand concrete, a bride or levee or a dam, but they’re not quite aware of green infrastructure as a potential solution.”• “Some people are steadfast gray infrastructure … because that’s what they’ve known.”

However, workshop participants also recognize that, from an equity standpoint, it is challenging to raise awareness about the different types of green infrastructure solutions, given the various types of communities, their size, location, and demographics. The result is that, as noted in the discussion, “there may be some inequities across our populations, in our neighborhoods, in level of awareness and familiarity with green infrastructure as a potential solution.” Those communities whose leaders or residents have prior knowledge of green infrastructure benefit from the inclusion of green infrastructure projects in strategic planning and implementation.

Workshop participants also discussed how, in the strategic planning and implementation phases, there can also be a disconnect between what the government wants, what it perceives stakeholders and the community want, and what stakeholders and the community want. One participant noted that “sometimes there’s just a huge disconnect in what the community actually wants to have happen and what the city, state, or local government is going to implement… I’ve seen this play out in New York City where a lot of low-income housing happens to be around the edges of Manhattan.” Using the example of Superstorm Sandy, they pointed to how this can lead to equity challenges associated with using green and gray infrastructure, where efforts to prevent future flooding may result in “diverting water to the Bronx, or to Brooklyn, or to other places… increasing the flood event for lower-income people that are not the lower part of Manhattan.” Distrust in the planning process can reduce public support for the resulting plan and projects that are implemented, especially if the project disproportionally benefits some communities at the expense of others. These can perpetuate inequities and further marginalize some communities who feel their input is unimportant and their voices are not heard. Furthermore, connecting this to the issue of buy-in and lack of awareness about green infrastructure, “the disconnect between what the community wants and how it’s being addressed and how that can generate distrust and frustration at the community level, which could prevent future endeavors of getting people on board.”

Participants were generally in agreement that stakeholder engagement and public participation during the first two phases of the strategic planning and implementation are crucial for addressing distrust, building support, and pursuing green infrastructure projects that are appropriate for the needs of different communities. Workshop participants did not raise many stakeholder engagement and public participation concerns regarding the maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation phase. This is not surprising, considering that engagement and participation are generally emphasized to a lesser degree during this phase. One comment that did come up was how, once the performance of a green infrastructure project has been determined, the evaluation results could be used “to communicate wins, to demonstrate what has worked.”

Trade-offs and Multiple Benefits: Consider Multiple Factors in ROI and Cost-Benefit Analysis

Workshop participants recognized that return on investment (ROI) and cost-benefit analysis are frequently used to evaluate and prioritize green infrastructure projects in the strategic planning and implementation phases. For example, one participant agreed that “return on investment and whatever formula is used to determine where the funding [for green infrastructure] should go.” However, workshop participants identified how project ROI varies across geographies, population groups, areas of risk, and other factors. For example, green infrastructure projects serving areas with lower property values and less dense development may generate lower ROI or higher cost-to-benefit ratios when property values are the primary drivers. Such areas have less chance of receiving funding for green infrastructure projects, and inequities may be exacerbated over time in low- or under-resourced communities. As noted by a workshop participant, “the more expensive the property, the more return on investment… the areas where the property values are lower have a less chance of getting funding for resiliency efforts. … areas of lower income and lower property values are the ones least likely to hit that return on investment.” Similarly, “for the US Army Corps of Engineers, the benefit-cost ratio is a big factor for deciding on their funding. And, of course, areas that are of greater value, because there are more expensive homes there, for example, the benefit-cost ratio will be more conducive to them having a project there.” More generally, the policy that relies on cost-benefit analysis “is a significant hurdle to funding nature-based solutions as a hazard mitigation technique” and may result in unintended consequences that are equity-related.

Workshop participants also acknowledged that equity considerations should be incorporated explicitly in ROI and cost-benefit analysis determination or be a clear factor in project prioritization. Specifically, they offered that co-benefits of green infrastructure should be included in the ROI and cost-to-benefit ratio analysis. For example, one workshop participant emphasized that green infrastructure adds “to the civic nature of the community and the ability to go out and use those green areas for socializing… there’s a social capital aspect that’s missing in that dialogue in terms of developing green infrastructure projects as opposed to gray infrastructure.” This social capital co-benefit illustrates the importance of focusing on people, “being mindful of what your communities’ issues are, particularly for the vulnerable parts of your community, and what matters most to them” when it comes to green infrastructure and coastal resilience. As another participant stated, “you’re really starting to ask that question about who are you trying to protect and what are their … differing needs in terms of [coastal] protection.” Other co-benefits of green infrastructure are associated with water quality regulations, and “stormwater, TMDL regulations, and the ability of green infrastructure to provide those co-benefits and also meet whatever water quality regulatory requirements that communities might have.” These co-benefits may also have environmental justice implications regarding front-line communities that are adversely impacted by pollution.

Resources and capacity: Lack of financial resources, limited staff capacity, and administrative burdens

Workshop participants emphasized how localities have varying resource capacities to plan for, seek funding, and implement green infrastructure projects. These differences can lead to inequities in terms of resources and capacity to pursue green infrastructure as a coastal resilience strategy. Financial resources and staff capacity are both challenges.

Lack of financial resources is a hurdle because of the costs of green infrastructure. As noted by workshop participants, “There’s a price tag often that’s associated with many of these [green infrastructure] improvements” and “If you’re even going to approach a green infrastructure solution, it’s big money.” However, there are “large differences in fiscal capacities among smaller governments in areas that are, especially areas that are fragmented into a lot of different cities.” In the words of a participant, the equity consequences are that “it might turn into a question of which communities … have the actual capacity to build some of this infrastructure which can be very expensive.”

Localities generally rely on grant funding such as the Hazard Mitigation Grants Program and the more recent Building Resilience Infrastructure and Communities (BRIC) grant program. However, workshop participants pointed out how under-resourced communities, such as small localities or those in rural areas, may not be able to develop a hazard mitigation plan that includes green infrastructure projects that could be funded with grants. Furthermore, funding for green infrastructure may be more readily accessible to communities that are knowledgeable of green infrastructure and its benefits, have plans and staff in place, and are organized. As succinctly summarized by a workshop participant, “one of the big issues is that many of the funding opportunities are easiest for already organized communities. If that community is plugged in and aware … has a good relationship with their government, it makes so much easier to get that funding opportunity started. They get to sort of leap past that whole community-building process and just start getting in that [project] pipeline.”

The grant process and requirements for green infrastructure projects can be arduous, including a lengthy application and review process, requirements for matching funds, and burdensome reporting and grant management. One workshop participant who is currently developing a new funding program succinctly summarized the equity concerns: “I’ve been thinking about that a lot, about minimizing the reporting requirements, the match requirements, all of the burdens that are typically associated with grant programs and how I don’t want us to become part of that problem. … how do we get money out … without being part of the burdensome grant problem…. [equity] is at the forefront.”

The federal grant matching funds requirement also contributes to inequities and disparities across communities. Referring to these requirements and their unintended consequences, one participant stated, “We know qualitatively that communities say it’s too hard for us to identify financial resources to contribute to meet certain requirements for some funding programs.” The cumbersome application process also prevents some localities from seeking or obtaining grant funding. In terms of applying for funding, one workshop participant noted that “there is a lot of funding out there if [localities] can figure out how to make that application.” However, even those localities able to apply are unable to secure grant funding. Using the example of the BRIC grant program, it was noted that “It has already been shown that a lot of the intended recipients of the grant funds aren’t approved because they just can’t [correctly] fill out the application.” Workshop participants also identified the disproportionate impacts of the heavy administrative burden of managing and reporting on grants. “We’ve been very fortunate with our mitigation grants. We have a very good grant coordinator… It’s a lot of hand holding [with grant recipients]. It’s a lot of sitting down and helping them fill out the paperwork and understanding how to submit for reimbursement.”

The discussion of financial resources for green infrastructure through federal grants highlights that resources and capacity are not solely funding-related. Localities need staff for strategic planning, implementation, maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation of green infrastructure. However, hiring and retaining staff and expertise are challenging. “There really is a lack of human resources that a lot of these communities face in terms of their staffing… ensuring that communities can hire technical staff and [have] technical capacities… if they don’t have the resources to do that with monetary and human resources, then these [green infrastructure] issues often are dead on arrival.” Another workshop participant noted, “If you don’t have the staff to do that, it’s probably not going to happen.” During the strategic planning phase, for example, one participant pointed to the importance of having staff knowledgeable of green infrastructure projects since awareness of and consideration of green infrastructure projects will be lacking “if there is nobody to advocate for, to champion these types of [green infrastructure] interventions at the professional staffing level.” Another workshop participant stated that “smaller communities may not have a planner” on staff who can support green infrastructure planning. In addition, some localities may not have the capacity to maintain and monitor the performance of green infrastructure once implemented. One workshop participant offered that “for some of the tribes along the Chesapeake Bay, the capacity to maintain some of these options influences the decision making.”

Finally, workshop participants also pointed to implications for green infrastructure strategic planning, implementation, and maintenance, monitoring and evaluation in terms of disparities between urban and rural localities. One participant noted how rural communities are generally underfunded and under-resourced, putting them at a significant disadvantage compared to more resourced urban localities. As a participant stated, “They’re really underfunded in these rural areas.”

Data, Metrics, and Analysis: Need for Data About and Maps of Green Infrastructure Projects

Workshop participants identified the need for quantitative and qualitative data to assess equity in the strategic planning, implementation, and maintenance, monitoring and evaluation of green infrastructure. However, they also recognized that there are significant gaps in the available data and the level of measurement for which data is collected. One workshop participant emphasized the limited availability of data for green infrastructure, stating that “there’s a lot of gaps, especially when you consider scale.” Having data at appropriate geographic and time-related scales is important. Regarding the time dynamic, “you have to consider temporal scales… land use is dynamic, health issues are dynamic, economic resources are dynamic.” Another participant stated that “green stormwater infrastructure, I don’t think that it is as well-mapped and assessed.” Workshop participants want data to show “what our government’s actually spending on green infrastructure in terms of resiliency.” However, this information on expenditures for green infrastructure is not clearly distinguished in the government’s budgets and financial reports or provided with sufficient detail, and the information is “just not always accurate.”

Databases and maps of green infrastructure projects are needed to fill this data gap for the benefit of all stages of green infrastructure planning. These databases and maps can include information on project location, owner, funding source, costs, benefits, and performance, because it could inform strategic planning, implementation, and maintenance of future green infrastructure projects. Workshop participants pointed to various green infrastructure projects supported by the National Coastal Resilience Fund and how “for all of these projects would be great to have a map of where all those projects are.”

Research Needs

A better understanding of how the implementation of green infrastructure projects considers equity within the three phases of our integrative framework is important for increasing the uptake of green infrastructure in a way that brings communities into the process, recognizes the key benefits and trade-offs, reconciles resources and capacities with the demands of green infrastructure, and provides data and metrics that support assessment of equity. Discussion in the workshop identified key gaps or questions that need to be addressed. Thus, we conclude our findings by identifying research questions that need to be addressed, as answering these questions will help improve our understanding of equity issues related to green infrastructure implementation. The questions are:• How is equity considered in communication and engagement with the public about green infrastructure?• How is equity considered in the funding of green infrastructure projects?• What are the equity impacts of grant program requirements for matching funds?• How is equity considered in the determination of benefits or costs of infrastructure projects?

Conclusion

In this study, we developed a new framework, the integrative planning framework, for implementing green infrastructure projects adapted from the urban planning framework, the systematic capital management and budgeting process, and the Connecting Nature framework. Findings from the workshop identified issues related to equity and coastal resilience across the three phases of the integrative planning framework of green infrastructure implementation.

Workshop participants also highlighted challenges including the (1) lack of buy-in due to limited awareness and distrust of government, (2) lack of financial resources, limited staff capacity, and administrative burdens, (3) need for additional data, metrics, and analysis, and (4) the need to consider multiple factors in ROI and cost/benefit analysis. The green infrastructure planning process should emphasize equity at each of the three stages—strategic planning, implementation, and maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation—to ensure that green infrastructure is implemented in a way that supports just and equitable communities.

The strategic planning phase considers the incorporation of green infrastructure into an array of public planning processes, such as land use, transportation, and economic development. It is essential to ensure that green infrastructure is explicitly embedded into the implementation of other strategic planning projects. Equity should be incorporated with a thorough analysis of local needs as well as budgeting of necessary projects during this phase. Equity is also ensured at this stage by diverse stakeholder engagement strategies, cross-functional collaborations, and project prioritization for underserved communities that should account for a wide range of benefits and tradeoffs beyond financial metrics.

The implementation phase assumes the execution of plans in the previous phase. It also involves fund allocation, assessment plans, contracting, and collaboration for project coordination and monitoring. Funding is central to the implementation phase because no project is initiated without the funding that backs it. Multi-level government grant funding, although available, requires complex coordination at different levels of government to ensure proper execution, possible matching funds requirements, extensive reporting, and intense coordination of various actors and activities that go into effective implementation. Here, equity can be incorporated through not only extensive public participation and education during funding allocation decisions but also by considering differences in resources and capacity that may inequitably put some communities at a disadvantage in applying, executing, and reporting on grant funding impacts.

Green infrastructure projects require ongoing maintenance, monitoring, and evaluation upon implementation. This phase should not be overlooked from the equity standpoint because it not only extends the life of the projects, which expands benefits to communities, but also helps to inform any future decisions regarding comprehensive infrastructure planning and to correct any potential misalignments with other government efforts, such as hazard mitigation. Evaluation can also be used to collect information about whether the projects are equitable in terms of communities they benefit over the long run as opposed to focusing solely on return on investment in the short term. Addressing externalities that are harder to quantify or even to assign benefits to specific projects is another important consideration for equity. There are intangible benefits that cannot be easily translated into hard data or metrics but can be more valuable as benefits to marginalized communities.

Every stage of the process within the integrative planning framework for green infrastructure implementation should incorporate equity considerations across four facets—stakeholder engagement and public participation; tradeoffs and multiple benefits; resources and capacity; and data, metrics, and analysis—if we are to correct the long-standing injustice of overlooking vulnerable and underserved communities associated with such projects. This study revealed key questions and areas of focus for social equity to be addressed in ways that promote and ensure fairness in the green infrastructure planning process.

This research is limited in context, given the audience that participated in the virtual workshop; hence, the findings may not apply to coastal areas beyond those that were represented in our sample. However, within the constraints and limitations of the project, the analysis uncovered common areas of concern that could apply to infrastructure planning processes more broadly, regardless of geographic region. Therefore, findings may be warranted for application in other coastal areas. Future studies may also add context-specific nuances, which would enrich and reinforce the practical application of this kind of research.

urn:contentItem:6GB1-6CM3-RWY7-125W-00000-00Reports Summarize Geography Study Results from Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee (Multiscale analysis of green infrastructure impacts on PM2.5 and PM10 pollution in Delhi, India)2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisSCIENCE - GEOGRAPHYReports Summarize Geography Study Results from Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee (Multiscale analysis of green infrastructure impacts on PM2.5 and PM10 pollution in Delhi, India)


2025 JUL 22 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on geography. According to news reporting out of the Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Urban air pollution, particularly from fine particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), poses critical environmental and public health challenges in rapidly urbanizing regions."


Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee: "This study presents a multiscale, seasonal analysis of the relationship between Green Infrastructure (GI) landscape characteristics and PM concentrations in Delhi, India. Using high-resolution Sentinel-2 imagery (2019-2021) and air quality data from 39 Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) monitoring stations, we quantified 15 GI characteristics across five spatial scales (0.5-2.5 km) using NDVI. Empirical Bayesian Kriging was applied for spatial interpolation of PM values, and Otsu's thresholding was used to delineate vegetated areas. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and regression models revealed that compositional metrics-such as Class Area (CA) and Percentage of Landscape (PLAND)-showed consistent negative correlations with PM2.5 and PM10 levels across all scales and seasons. Configuration metrics, including Largest Patch Index (LPI), Edge Density (ED), and Aggregation Index (AI), exhibited scaleand season-specific influences, with stronger effects observed at broader spatial scales during winter and autumn. The findings suggest that both the quantity and spatial arrangement of urban vegetation significantly affect local air quality."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The study underscores the need for scale-aware, evidence-based GI planning as a nature-based solution, supporting India's airshed-level approach to urban pollution management. These insights offer practical guidance for urban policymakers and planners aiming to enhance air quality through strategic green infrastructure design."
For more information on this research see: Multiscale analysis of green infrastructure impacts on PM2.5 and PM10 pollution in Delhi, India. Geographica Pannonica, 2025,29(2):149-171. (Geographica Pannonica - http://scindeks.ceon.rs/journalDetails.aspx?issn=0354-8724&lang=en). The publisher for Geographica Pannonica is University of Novi Sad, Department of Geography, Tourism and Hotel Management.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.5937/gp29-53959.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Kumar Atul, Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee.
Keywords for this news article include: Indian Institute of Technology Roorkee, Geography, Science.

urn:contentItem:6GJK-YTR3-RVD0-W3W7-00000-00MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT ISSUES NEW STORMWATER PERMIT FOR TRANSPORTATION, EXPANDING GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisMARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT ISSUES NEW STORMWATER PERMIT FOR TRANSPORTATION, EXPANDING GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIESStates News ServiceBALTIMORE, MD

The following information was released by the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE):

Expanded permit requirements and additional actions advance climate resilience, clean water goals, and healthy communities

BALTIMORE (August 22, 2025) The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) today released the next five-year stormwater discharge permit for the Maryland Department of Transportation's State Highway Administration (MDOT SHA), designed to deliver economic opportunities for communities, cleaner waterways, and enhanced climate resilience.

The new Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) permit expands MDOT SHA's restoration obligations to more than 4,000 acres (a nearly 40% increase in restored acres over the draft permit). The effort is supported by $216 million in combined state and federal funding and is expected to support Maryland's growing restoration economy while protecting vulnerable communities from flooding and pollution.

"This permit strengthens our ability to protect the Chesapeake Bay and the businesses and communities that rely on it, manage stormwater in overburdened areas, and make our state an even more desirable place to live," said Maryland Environment Secretary Serena McIlwain. "This permit and other actions the Department is announcing today will help build a more competitive Maryland creating good-paying jobs, protecting businesses and homes from the effects of climate change, and positioning our state as a national leader in clean infrastructure."

"Building and maintaining a safer transportation system that drives economic growth starts with protecting one of the state's most treasured assets our environment," said Maryland Department of Transportation Acting Secretary Samantha J. Biddle. "MDOT continues to work toward addressing transportation-related stormwater needs to protect Marylanders from flooding and to advance clean rivers and streams in our communities."

Permit highlights include:

Requires MDOT SHA to restore 4,092 impervious acres through stormwater retrofits and other practices, with a focus on green infrastructure such as stream restoration and tree planting across the roadway network

Increases equity and accountability by requiring MDOT SHA to evaluate and report on restoration opportunities and progress in communities with environmental justice concerns, while meeting annual benchmarks to ensure steady progress

Modernizes tracking by expanding collaboration with scientists and experts on shared monitoring studies delivering better data, faster results, and smarter decisions.

The enhanced permit reflects public input including a public hearing and formal comment period when MDE carefully considered feedback and incorporated changes on restoration goals, equity, and monitoring and is part of a broader package of clean water and climate initiatives that MDE is pursuing under the Moore-Miller Administration. These include:

Updating stormwater regulations based on future climate conditions

Updating erosion and sediment control requirements in coordination with stormwater regulations to ensure modern, climate-resilient design standards.

Improving guidance and tools for living shorelines and resilient wetlands, including new guidance to implement the Whole Watersheds Act

Forming a workgroup to collaborate on a long-term shared vision for future MS4 stormwater goals and regulations

Adding nearly $2.5 million in funding for flood risk studies

urn:contentItem:6GGP-JJ53-RY2R-V1GX-00000-00Investigators at Norwegian University of Life Sciences Describe Findings in Climate Change (Green Infrastructure's Potential Effects On Climate Change Adaptation In Cold-climate Countries: a Critical Literature Review)2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEInvestigators at Norwegian University of Life Sciences Describe Findings in Climate Change (Green Infrastructure's Potential Effects On Climate Change Adaptation In Cold-climate Countries: a Critical Literature Review)


2025 AUG 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in Climate Change. According to news originating from As, Norway, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Over the past decade, the concept of 'green infrastructure' (GI) has been gaining attention in attempts to tackle climate change challenges. However, a knowledge gap persists in understanding the evolving conceptualization, core principles, and contribution of GI and its potential benefits for cold-climate cities and societies in adapting to climate change."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from the Norwegian University of Life Sciences, "This article presents the outcomes of a critical review of studies on GI in cold-climate contexts. Findings reveal that there is a layering of focuses on GI, which derive from different scientific approaches and may support different agendas and actors within climate adaptation discourses. GI has been recognized as a tool to address not only climate adaptation challenges (e.g., urban heat islands, human well-being, urban stormwater runoff), but also those related to urbanization and loss of biodiversity. The potential benefits of GI and its components (such as trees, urban parks, green roofs and green walls) include the reduction of urban heating islands and temperature, supporting human health and well-being, increasing urban biodiversity, and managing stormwater."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This study contributes to providing an overview of GI in cold-climate countries and sharing it with practitioners and stakeholders, to support them in developing policies, planning strategies and practices, for the benefit of people and nature."
This research has been peer-reviewed.
For more information on this research see: Green Infrastructure's Potential Effects On Climate Change Adaptation In Cold-climate Countries: a Critical Literature Review. Sustainable Development, 2025. Sustainable Development can be contacted at: Wiley, 111 River St, Hoboken 07030-5774, NJ, USA. urn:contentItem:6G4F-YN53-RT41-M4B3-00000-00Research Reports on Environment from Mohammed First University Provide New Insights (Strategies For Managing and Maintaining Green Infrastructure: Review)2025-06-26T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisENVIRONMENTResearch Reports on Environment from Mohammed First University Provide New Insights (Strategies For Managing and Maintaining Green Infrastructure: Review)


2025 JUN 26 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Ecology Daily News -- Research findings on environment are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting originating from Mohammed First University by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Green spaces are essential infrastructures for improving quality of life, promoting biodiversity and responding to environmental challenges in urban areas."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Mohammed First University: "Their management requires a systemic approach combining strategic planning and regular maintenance. This review examines the various aspects of this management, including the organisation of green infrastructure, the public policies that support it, urban planning and appropriate maintenance strategies. It also sheds light on the different modes of governance, while analysing the contribution of available resources, whether human, material or financial, to their effectiveness and resilience. The design and management of green infrastructure is based on active cooperation between the various stakeholders, from decision-makers to citizens. This cooperation ensures an inclusive approach that is tailored to the specific needs of each area, thereby maximising their positive impact. This collective work helps to take account of different perspectives, ensuring sustainable and coherent solutions for urban well-being."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "This study highlights the importance of green spaces as pillars of urban sustainability, using a rigorous literature review to explore green infrastructure management practices. It highlights an approach that goes beyond planting to incorporate a long-term, strategic and sustainable vision."
For more information on this research see: Strategies For Managing and Maintaining Green Infrastructure: Review. E3S Web of Conferences, 2025,632():01014. (E3S Web of Conferences - http://www.e3s-conferences.org/). The publisher for E3S Web of Conferences is EDP Sciences.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1051/e3sconf/202563201014.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Chkird Fadoua, Laboratory for the Improvement of Agricultural Production, Biotechnology and Environment, Department of Biology, Faculty of Sciences, Mohammed First University. Additional authors for this research include Derouiche Mourad, Boukhaffa Chaymae, Lafdil Mohamed, Mzabri Ibtissam, Boukroute Azzouz, Berrichi Abdelbasset, Kouddane Noureddine.
Keywords for this news article include: Mohammed First University, Environment.

urn:contentItem:6GMY-0H03-RSYK-S1NX-00000-00Ian Mell2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisIan Mell

Link to Image

Link to Story

Professor in Environmental & Landscape Planning,University of Manchester

ProfileArticlesActivityIan joined the University of Manchester in 2017 from the University of Liverpool where he spent over five years working in the Department of Geography & Planning.
Ian's career has included a variety of academic (BSc Northumbria, MSc Sussex, PhD Newcastle), practitioner and contract consultancy roles in the UK, Europe and internationally . These have enabled him to bring together Local Government and practical policy-making/delivery experiences into the teaching and research environment through a practical understanding of how policy is formed, how decision-making occurs, and how implementation is delivered.


Aligning an understanding of these approaches to planning underpins Ian's work on urban greening, Green Infrastructure planning and landscape policy. This examines the relationship between policy and practice in the discussion, development and evaluation of urban greening. It also provides scope to evaluate the changing landscape of planning policy and its impacts upon the delivery of sustainable or meaningful places.
Ian's work focusses on a number of areas of urban greening including financing green space delivery, the role of perceptions in sustainable cities, and the influence of various actors on the decision-making process for environmental management. Part of this process is developing a better understanding of how rhetoric and delivery differ in the planning and management of cities.
Ian has received funding from NERC, the Valuing Nature project, RTPI, Defra/Natural England and the Newton Fund to support research into green infrastructure policy, perceptions and practice in the UK and internationally. He has also worked with UN Habitat and the Landscape Research Group to examine the utility of planning and landscape policy.
Outside of academia Ian has experience of green infrastructure practice through working with advocacy organisations (Community Forests in North-East England, 2005-2008) and as a Green Infrastructure Development Officer in East Cambridgeshire (2009-2011) where he coordinated the delivery of the £1 million Ely Country Park Project and was a key strategic partners in the production of the the 2nd Cambridgeshire Green Infrastructure Strategy (Cambridgeshire Horizons, 2011). He was also an author of the Liverpool Green & Open Space Review (2015-16), which assessed the nature of green space funding in Liverpool and started to identify where new sources of financial support could be located.
Experience

2017-presentLecturer in Environmental Planning, University of Manchester

Education

urn:contentItem:6G5Y-SGV3-RS26-W1MF-00000-00Reports from Wuhan University Add New Data to Research in Remote Sensing (Estimation of carbon sequestration capacity of urban green infrastructure by fusing multi-source remote sensing data)2025-07-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisREMOTE SENSINGReports from Wuhan University Add New Data to Research in Remote Sensing (Estimation of carbon sequestration capacity of urban green infrastructure by fusing multi-source remote sensing data)


2025 JUL 03 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Research findings on remote sensing are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting out of Wuhan, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "Urban green infrastructure significantly contributes to the carbon storage functions of urban ecosystems."


Financial supporters for this research include Major Science And Technology Special Projects And Key R & D Projects in Yunnan Province in 2024; Fundamental Research Fund Program of Liesmars; National Natural Science Foundation of China; National Key Research And Development Program of China; Sichuan Provincial Science And Technology Support Program.
The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Wuhan University: "Accurate selection and efficiently integrating remote sensing data are paramount for evaluating carbon storage at the small-scale of urban green infrastructure. In this study, evaluating the precision of carbon storage estimation by integrating UAV-acquired multi-view spectral images and LiDAR data, complemented by ground-truth validation data. The allometric equations and carbon ratios specific to the tree species. The accuracy evaluation reveals that the R2 value and RMSE for the extracted individual tree height variables were 0.75 and 1.76 m. For the estimated carbon storage, the R2 reached 0.86, with an RMSE of 28.88 kg C. Additionally, the spatial arrangement and structure of tree species within green infrastructure notably affected carbon storage heterogeneity."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "This study demonstrates the effectiveness of integrating multi-view spectral imagery and LiDAR in accurately estimating carbon storage in urban green infrastructure. Furthermore, incorporating the small-scale spatial patterns of tree species can enhance the precision of carbon storage estimation."
For more information on this research see: Estimation of carbon sequestration capacity of urban green infrastructure by fusing multi-source remote sensing data. International Journal of Applied Earth Observations and Geoinformation, 2025,141():104643. The publisher for International Journal of Applied Earth Observations and Geoinformation is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2025.104643.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Jiahui Chang, State Key Laboratory of Information Engineering in Surveying, Mapping and Remote Sensing, Wuhan University, Wuhan 430079, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Zhenfeng Shao, Jinyang Wang, Zhu Mao, Tao Cheng, Xiaodi Xu, Qingwei Zhuang.
Keywords for this news article include: Wuhan University, Wuhan, People's Republic of China, Asia, Remote Sensing.

urn:contentItem:6GGP-JHN3-RXWH-J388-00000-00Researchers' from University of Coimbra Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Invasive Species (Are Urban Green Spaces' Attributes Relevant to Explain the Occurrence of Invasive Species Within Urban Green Infrastructure?)2025-08-13T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisECOLOGY - INVASIVE SPECIESResearchers' from University of Coimbra Report Details of New Studies and Findings in the Area of Invasive Species (Are Urban Green Spaces' Attributes Relevant to Explain the Occurrence of Invasive Species Within Urban Green Infrastructure?)


2025 AUG 13 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- A new study on invasive species is now available. According to news originating from Coimbra, Portugal, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Despite the importance of Urban Green Infrastructure (UGI) as a provider of multiple Ecosystem Services (ESs), some concerns have been raised regarding Ecosystem Disservices (EDs) associated with UGI design and management, namely, the link between Urban Green Spaces' (UGSs) attributes and invasion spatial patterns."


Funders for this research include FundacaO Para A Ciencia E Tecnologia, I. P.
Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from University of Coimbra: "This research takes the UGI of Coimbra, a medium-sized Portuguese city, as a case study to explore the relationships between UGS attributes and the occurrence of invasive plant species. The methodology involved aerial photo-interpretation and full patch survey to collect data about UGSs types, maintenance level and occurrence of invasive plant species, and landscape metrics analysis. Our results showed that the UGI of Coimbra exhibits a large prevalence of small UGSs with regular maintenance and the occurrence of invasive plant species in a low number of patches (17%). Although these patches correspond to 64% of the UGI. The area of recent sprawl (zone 2) registers higher occurrence of invasive plant species across different UGSs types, with higher prevalence in patches with no or low maintenance."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Mapping the occurrence of invasive plant species in UGS is of utmost importance to implement appropriate maintenance practices, allowing medium-sized cities like Coimbra to optimize ESs associated with UGI and minimize potential EDs."
For more information on this research see: Are Urban Green Spaces' Attributes Relevant to Explain the Occurrence of Invasive Species Within Urban Green Infrastructure?. Urban Science, 2025,9(7):260. (Urban Science - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/urbansci). The publisher for Urban Science is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/urbansci9070260.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Monica Andrade, Department of Life Sciences, University of Coimbra, 3000-456 Coimbra, Portugal. Additional authors for this research include Claudia Fernandes, Albano Figueiredo.
Keywords for this news article include: University of Coimbra, Coimbra, Portugal, Europe, Ecology, Environment, Invasive Species, Life Science Research.

urn:contentItem:6GB7-6253-RVBW-S3MF-00000-00Data on Climate Change Detailed by Researchers at University of Belgrade (Flowering Patterns of <i>cornus Mas</i> L. In the Landscape Phenology of Roadside Green Infrastructure Under Climate Change Conditions In Serbia)2025-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-09-15T21:07:37ZLexisNexisCLIMATE CHANGEData on Climate Change Detailed by Researchers at University of Belgrade (Flowering Patterns of <i>cornus Mas</i> L. In the Landscape Phenology of Roadside Green Infrastructure Under Climate Change Conditions In Serbia)


2025 JUL 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Climate Change Daily News -- Research findings on Climate Change are discussed in a new report. According to news reporting from Belgrade, Serbia, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "One of the emerging services provided by roadside green infrastructure is its contribution to the quality of landscape phenology, which is measured through the succession of colours and forms throughout the seasons. In the seasonal dynamics of space, flowering phenological patterns play a key role, particularly in early blooming species such as Cornus mas L. Therefore, this paper aims to highlight the significance of the Cornelian cherry as a component of roadside green infrastructure in the southwestern suburban zone of Belgrade."


Financial support for this research came from Ministry of Science, Technological Development and Innovation of the Republic of Serbia.
The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from the University of Belgrade, "Through an integrative approach to phenological and climatic elements, and by means of a specific case study covering the period from 2007 to 2025, under climate change conditions, the influence of air temperature and precipitation on local flowering patterns of the Cornelian cherry has been assessed. Based on 1140 phenological observations conducted over 19 consecutive years, from January to April, key flowering elements were identified-those that influence pollination, fruiting, and the species' practical potential. The Mann-Kendall, Sen's slope, Rayleigh, and Watson-Williams tests were used to examine spatio-temporal changes in flowering patterns, while the Spearman Rank test and circular statistics were applied to quantify correlations among the analysed parameters. The results confirm that Cornelian cherry is an adaptive and sustainable species that continuously provides visual identity during its flowering period, while simultaneously reflecting climate change through phenological responses. These phenological responses are closely linked to local climatic conditions. In addition to enriching landscape phenology with vibrant visual features during the colder months, Cornelian cherry also enhances biodiversity by providing ecosystem services as a nectar-producing species, with its pollen serving as an early and valuable food source for bees."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The study also confirms that the seasonal dynamics of landscape phenology can be used as a scientifically valid criterion for assessing the ecological quality of roadside green infrastructure."
For more information on this research see: Flowering Patterns of <i>cornus Mas</i> L. In the Landscape Phenology of Roadside Green Infrastructure Under Climate Change Conditions In Serbia. Sustainability, 2025;17(12):5334. Sustainability can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Djurdja Petrov, University of Belgrade, Faculty of Forestry, Dept. of Landscape Architecture and Horticulture, Kneza Viseslava 1, Belgrade 11030, Serbia. Additional authors for this research include Mirjana Ocokoljic, Nevenka Galecic, Dejan Skocajic, Jelena Cukanovic, Sara Dordevic and Radenka Kolarov.
The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.3390/su17125334. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.
Keywords for this news article include: Belgrade, Serbia, Europe, Climate Change, Global Warming, University of Belgrade.
